ygData.msgSnippet: Actually it is probably the reverse problem - search for a small molecule (or shape) that is expected to bind best to a given protein binding site which is

Actually it is probably the reverse problem - search for a small
molecule (=
or shape) that is expected to bind best to a given protein
binding site whi=
ch is considered static.  Actually, this starts to
become very interesting.=
  Suppose I have a set of compounds that I
know bind well to a particular p=
rotein - a training set.  If I can use
CPPN or HyperNEAT to establish a gen=
eralizable assessment of the
ability of a compound to bind, I then in effec=
t have a map of good
features and bad features.  The next trick would be to=
 find a compound
that maximally meets those criteria.  This aspect could be=
 done by
screening pre-existing databases of compounds, or perhaps even
bui=
lding one from scratch.  This actually starts to resemble a
fundamental pro=
blem in computational drug design.  Often we have
access to many chemicals =
that have the activity we want, but those are
owned by other companies.  To=
 identify new chemical matter we have to
do something called "Scaffold Hopp=
ing" which consists of using
existing chemical information but changing the=
 core structures such
that they are outside of any pre-owned chemical space=
.  This is much
harder than if appears as it is often hard to keep the same=
 chemical
substituents in the right place on a new scaffold.

Also, we have=
 both converged on HyperNEAT.  After reading some more of
the references yo=
u suggested, I'm thinking HyperNEAT is indeed a
potential option.  I'm thin=
g that representing the binding site of the
protein as a 3D grid with point=
s spaced at 1 angstrom apart.  The
(x,y,z) input could correspond to partic=
ular small molecule or protein
(or both) atom types or properties that exis=
t at those locations. 
Representing both atom types may be interesting as i=
t would allow
identification of beneficial pairings of atoms between protei=
n and
ligand.  

I agree that the details need to be fleshed out somewhat. =
 I'm
planning to do some additional reading and hopefully start working on
=
some details.  Please feel free to offer further suggestions.

If only I ha=
d a bored grad student or intern to set on this one.  8^)



--- In neat@ya=
hoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> It seems like at=
 first glance the simplest thing to do with a CPPN
> would be to search for=
 the shape or comformation of some protein or
> molecule that would produce=
 some sort of desired binding.  However,
> that is not exactly the problem =
you are describing; rather, you are
> suggesting something more like a scor=
ing system that looks at two
> interacting pieces and rates their interacti=
on.  Perhaps something
> like that would be served well by HyperNEAT, which=
 can form a neural
> network based on the geometric configuration of its in=
puts.  The
> possibilities would obviously need to still be fleshed out.
> =

> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "newtwist2000" <rkdelisle@> wrote:=

> >
> > You've captured the basic idea.  Let me expand on it a bit.
> > 
>=
 > One of the currently leading problems in computational chemistry or
> > =
molecular modeling is coming up with a method to predict the affinity
> > o=
f a small molecule for the binding site of a protein.  In the case
> > wher=
e you have a model of the binding site (typically from a crystal
> > struct=
ure), there are tools that will accurately position a small
> > molecule in=
to the binding site, however, there is not a good scoring
> > function that=
 will give you an estimate of the activity that small
> > molecule will hav=
e against the protein.  It seems counter-intuitive -
> > we can accurately =
place the molecule in the right 3D conformation into
> > the 3D binding sit=
e, but we can't really tell you how active it will
> > be.  In other cases =
you do not have a model of the protein.  In both
> > cases you may have a n=
umber of compounds for which the activity is
> known.
> > 
> > For small mo=
lecules to bind to a protein/enzyme, they will be required
> > to make a nu=
mber of interactions with that protein.  This implies that
> > they must be=
 the correct shape, obviously, but they must also place
> > the correct typ=
es of atoms/groups in the right place to make those
> > interactions.  Ofte=
n, the bulk of the compound is used to place things
> > into the right loca=
tions in order to get an interaction - to get the
> > right shape.
> > 
> >=
 Given the CPPN's ability to capture spatial relationships, I'm
> > wonderi=
ng if it could be used as an evaluator for the strength of an
> > interacti=
on of this sort.  The spatial relationships of interest may
> > stem from t=
he small molecules themselves, the protein binding site, or
> > a combinati=
on of the two.  All of this is going on in a 3D space
> > defined by the pr=
otein binding site.
> > 
> > Obviously I need to think about this further, =
but there very well may
> > be something useful here that hasn't yet been t=
ried.  
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken=
neth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Kirk, I think that's a very in=
teresting potential application
area.  
> > > Let me make sure I'm understa=
nding how it would work.  You are
saying
> > > that you might capture the s=
hape of a protein binding region (or
some
> > > other important region) wit=
h a CPPN and then use that CPPN-encoded
> > > model to test other chemical =
compounds?  
> > > 
> > > But if you already have a model of the intended s=
hape, what
additional
> > > capability would the CPPN provide other than en=
coding the 3D model
> > > that you already have?  Or do you mean you might =
try creating new
> > > shapes with the CPPN that you haven't thought of and=
 see how they
> > > react with known compounds?  There are probably other w=
ays it
could go
> > > as well, but I'm curious from the point of view of co=
mputational
> > > chemistry where the most exciting opportunity would be.  =

> > > 
> > > ken
> > > 
> > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "newtwist2000" =
<rkdelisle@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > I may be over-interpreting the CPPN pro=
cess, but it stimulated
a few
> > > > ideas.  I work in the field of Comput=
ational Chemistry and my
in my
> > > > day to day operations I deal with dr=
ug-like chemical
compounds.  The
> > > > 3D shape of a chemical is a princi=
ple determining factor of its
> > > > activity.  On top of 3D shape, you ha=
ve different functional
groups
> > > > that impart different properties.  F=
or example, let's say the
> shape is
> > > > just right to bind to a partic=
ular enzyme (and prevent it from
> running
> > > > amok) but you need an ox=
ygen atom at a particular location, or a
> > > > nitrogen, or any atom with=
 a hydrogen attached, etc.
> > > > 
> > > > There are two ways to get to th=
is type of information.  First is
> > > > having a large collection of chem=
icals with a known endpoint.  For
> > > > this I usually apply the standard=
 pattern recognition tools. 
> Another
> > > > more difficult approach is w=
hen you don't have much data for
> > > > chemicals, but you know the 3D str=
ucture of the enzyme and
where you
> > > > want your chemical to bind.  I'm=
 wondering if there is an
> application
> > > > for CPPNs here.  Can the CP=
PN capture the shape of the site
> along with
> > > > the essential propert=
ies based on the protein itself and then be
> used
> > > > to assess differ=
ent chemical compounds that have not yet been
> tested -
> > > > try to pre=
dict their activities.
> > > > 
> > > > Any thoughts??
> > > > 
> > > > -Ki=
rk
> > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth=
 Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > Kirk, what is your idea fo=
r applying CPPNs to pattern
> > recognition?  I
> > > > > am not sure I fol=
lowed exactly how the CPPN would be connected
> > to the
> > > > > neural n=
etwork?
> > > > > 
> > > > > As Peter mentioned, we have used the idea of C=
PPNs to represent
> > > > > connectivity patterns rather than the spatial p=
atterns you saw
> > in the
> > > > > CPPN paper.  These connectivity patter=
ns can then be
> interpreted of
> > > > > neural network connectivity patte=
rns, which means you can evolve
> > > > > neural networks with regularities=
 in their connectivities. 
> > There are
> > > > > currently four papers on=
 this approach to evolving ANNs with
> CPPNs,
> > > > > which is called Hyp=
erNEAT.  Those papers are available from my
> > > homepage
> > > > > 
> > >=
 > > http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/
> > > > > 
> > > > > or from EPlex pu=
blications:
> > > > > 
> > > > > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications.html
=
> > > > > 
> > > > > The particular papers are:
> > > > > 
> > > > > -A Nov=
el Generative Encoding for Exploiting Neural Network
> > Sensor and 
> > > =
> > Output Geometry
> > > > > 
> > > > > -Generating Large-Scale Neural Net=
works Through Discovering
> > Geometric
> > > > > Regularities 
> > > > > 
=
> > > > > -A Case Study on the Critical Role of Geometric Regularity in
> >=
 Machine
> > > > > Learning
> > > > > 
> > > > > -Generative Encoding for M=
ultiagent Learning 
> > > > > 
> > > > > A longer journal paper on HyperNEA=
T is also forthcoming in
> > Artificial
> > > > > Life journal.
> > > > > 
=
> > > > > By the way, you can also interactively evolve your own CPPNs
> im=
ages
> > > > > online at http://picbreeder.org
> > > > > 
> > > > > Because=
 spatial patterns and connectivity patterns can represent
> > just
> > > > =
> about anything, there are other potential applications of CPPNs
> > beyon=
d
> > > > > representing ANNs, but currently there is no publication of
> s=
uch an
> > > > > application that I know of.  But it would be interesting t=
o
> see more
> > > > > work in that direction.
> > > > > 
> > > > > ken 
> =

i"

 uses CPPNs to build the neural network phenotypes

ves CPPNs). I see this as an extension. There are
about 3 or

 is
